review.title: On the String Kernel Pre-Image Problem with Applications in Drug Discovery
review.abstract: The pre-image problem has to be solved during inference by most structured output predictors. For string kernels, this problem corresponds to finding the string associated to a given input. An algorithm capable of solving or finding good approximations to this problem would have many applications in computational biology and other fields. This work uses a recent result on combinatorial optimization of linear predictors based on string kernels to develop, for the pre-image, a low complexity upper bound valid for many string kernels. This upper bound is used with success in a branch and bound searching algorithm. Applications and results in the discovery of druggable peptides are presented and discussed.
histories: Peer-reviewed and accepted for presentation at Machine Learning in Computational Biology 2014, Montr\'{e}al, Qu\'{e}bec, Canada

metadata.title: On the String Kernel Pre-Image Problem with Applications in Drug Discovery

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This work focuses on the challenges of using regression learning algorithms in the conception of highly active peptides. Let A be the set of all amino acids and A the set of all possible peptides. In this work we assume that we have a dataset S = (x1, e1),., (xm, em)., (xm, em), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (xp), (, (,), (, (,), (, (,), (, (,), (, (,,,), (, (,,), (, (,,,), (, (,), (,, (,), (, (,), (, (,), (, (,), (,, (,), (,,,, (,), (,,,,, (,,,,,, (,),,, (,,,,,,, (,,,,,,,,), (, (,), (, (,), (, (,), (, (,), (, (,), (,), (, (,), (, (,), (,), (,, (, (,),, (, (,), (, (,),, (, (,), (,, (,), (, (, (, (,),), (, (, (, (,,), (, (,), (,), (, (, (, (,),

sections.heading: 2 Method
sections.text: Since the number of peptides grows exponentially with their length, it becomes impossible to evaluate all solutions for large peptides, so we propose a split and bound scheme to conduct this search. A split and bound algorithm starts by dividing the search space into individual sub-areas. A sub-space could then be divided into smaller sub-areas when a sub-space can no longer be divided (a leaf is reached in the search tree), or when the upper limit is lower than the value of a solution already achieved (i.e., a leaf already reached in the search tree). A branch and a bound approach can therefore avoid exploring a large part of the search space.

sections.heading: 3 Results and Discussion
sections.text: We followed the protocol presented in [6] to identify the pesticides and used the same data sets they used: 101 cationic antimicrobial pentadecaptides (CAMPs) from the synthetic antibiotic peptide database [8]. Peptide antibacterial activities, however, are expressed as a logarithm of bacterial potency. As in [6], we used kernel-based regression as a learning algorithm. Apart from the fact that all hyper parameters for the GS kernel (k, σc, σc) and kernel-based regression (f) were chosen by standard cross-validation, we learned two predictors of antimicrobial potency, one uses unnormalized kernel values (i.e. the same predictor used in [6].

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: Empirical results show that the method proposed by [6] may suffer from a dominance of the norm for certain strings, a problem present in many string nuclei. In these situations, it could be shown that the proposed method overcomes this problem. Narrower limits should exploit the proposed framework and allow the discovery of new peptide inhibitors. Finally, applications for medicines based on cyclic peptides and other structured output applications are expected.

referenceMentions.context: For few kernels like the Hamming kernel, solving Equation (2) is trivial [1].
However, this kernel is not well suited for peptides [2].
On another hand, the Generic String (GS) kernel [2] is well suited for peptides.

Depending on the chosen hyper-parameters, this kernel can be specialized to eight known kernels [2], namely the Hamming kernel, the Blended Spectrum [3], the Radial Basis Function (RBF), the Oligo [4], and the Weighted degree [5].

Depending on the chosen hyper-parameters, this kernel can be specialized to eight known kernels [2], namely the Hamming kernel, the Blended Spectrum [3], the Radial Basis Function (RBF), the Oligo [4], and the Weighted degree [5].

It was recently shown [6] that when K is the Generic String (GS) kernel, and when we restrict peptides to be of length l, the peptide x ∈ Al can be found in polynomial time for any predictor h in the form of Equation (1).
Hence, let us consider the strings “AAAAA” and “ABCDE” and the Spectrum kernel [7] (also known as the n-gram kernel) with k-mers of size two.
For g(x, l), note that ∑m i=1 βiK(xi,x) is what [6] proposed to maximize.
The computation of g is thus very efficient, the algorithm of [6] only needs to be done once before the branch and bound search, then g(x, l) can be computed in constant time for any x.

3 Results and Discussion We followed the protocol suggested by [6] and, as a proof of concept, we used the same dataset they used: 101 cationic antimicrobial pentadecapeptides (CAMPs) from the synthetic antibiotic peptides database [8].

3 Results and Discussion We followed the protocol suggested by [6] and, as a proof of concept, we used the same dataset they used: 101 cationic antimicrobial pentadecapeptides (CAMPs) from the synthetic antibiotic peptides database [8].
As in [6], we used kernel ridge regression as the learning algorithm.
We learned two predictors of antimicrobial potency, one uses unnormalized kernel values (thus, the same predictor used in [6]), the other was trained using normalized kernel values.
The method presented in [6] was used to identify the peptide x ∈ A15 of maximal predicted bioactivity according to h and the branch and bound was used to identify x⋆ ∈ A15, the peptide maximizing h⋆.
The method of [6] uses a k-longest path algorithm to obtain the k peptides of maximal bioactivity.
This suggests that the method of [6] offers some resistance to variation in norm when σp is small.
The method of [6] found the peptide “FKKIFKKIFKKIFKF” using the predictor h and the branch and bound approach found the peptide “WKKIFKKIWKFRVFK” using the predictorh⋆.
Empirical results show that the method proposed by [6] can suffer from a dominance of the norm for certain strings, a problem which is present

metadata.abstractText: The pre-image problem has to be solved during inference by most structured output predictors. For string kernels, this problem corresponds to finding the string associated to a given input. An algorithm capable of solving or finding good approximations to this problem would have many applications in computational biology and other fields. This work uses a recent result on combinatorial optimization of linear predictors based on string kernels to develop, for the pre-image, a low complexity upper bound valid for many string kernels. This upper bound is used with success in a branch and bound searching algorithm. Applications and results in the discovery of druggable peptides are presented and discussed.
